The 2017 Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded to three scientists for their contributions to the field of gravitational waves. The award was given to Rainer Weiss, Barry Barish, and Kip Thorne for their work in detecting gravitational waves, which were first predicted by Albert Einstein's theory of general relativity over a century ago. The discovery of gravitational waves has opened up a new way of observing the universe, allowing scientists to study some of the most violent and energetic events in the cosmos, such as the collisions of black holes and neutron stars. The prize was announced on October 3, 2017, and each recipient received a medal, a diploma, and a cash award of 9 million Swedish kronor (approximately $1.1 million USD). The award ceremony took place on December 10, 2017, in Stockholm, Sweden.
